title: Perform an integration with Operations Orchestration Containerized
content:
Prerequisites

Before you proceed, make sure that you have met the following prerequisites:

  • Your suite admin has installed OO Containerized on the same OMT as Service Management. For details, see the relevant sections in Install. 
  • Your suite admin has deployed and enabled the Operations Orchestration capability in Suite Administration. For detailed steps, see Deploy OO Containerized in Suite Administration.
  • You have installed the OPB Agent and added an agent. For details, see How to use On-Premises Bridge agents on Windows and How to use On-Premises Bridge agents on Linux.
  • If the Operations Orchestration flow you are importing uses encryption, you have set up encryption between Service Management and the OPB agent before you perform the integration. For more information, see How to set up encryption for an Operations Orchestration integration.

To set up the integration, the suite admin and tenant admin need to perform the following tasks.

Tasks for the suite admin

The suite admin needs to perform the following tasks.

Create two integration users for the tenant in Suite Administration

To use OO Containerized, the tenant admin needs to integrate Service Management with OO through the On-Premises Bridge (OPB) Agent. The OPB Agent needs two integration users: one is used to access Service Management and the other to access OO.  

 If there's already an OPB Agent installed for the tenant, a Service Management integration user is already available, and the suite admin only needs to create one integration user for OO. 

To create an integration user in Suite Administration for the tenant:

  1. Log in to Suite Administration as suite-admin: https:<External Access Host>/bo.
  2. Click Users and then click New.
  3. Select the tenant's account and select Integration user as the user type.
  4. Complete the other fields as needed to create the user. 
  5. Open the tenant, and click IdM settings to open the IdM Admin Portal, locate the integration user, and click Reset Password to set a password for the integration user. 

Next, the suite admin needs to grant the required permissions to the OO integration user, and the tenant admin needs to grant the OPB Remote Agent role to the Service Management integration user. 

Configure OO permissions for the OO integration user in the IdM Admin Portal

  1. In Suite Administration, click the IdM settings tab of the tenant.
  2. Click Users, and then locate the OO integration user.
  3. Assign the OO Administrators role to the user and then click Save.

Assign OO permissions to users

Users need different permissions to work in different areas in OO Containerized. Configure users with different permissions for OO Containerized. For more information, see Roles and permissions in OO Central.

Tasks for the tenant admin

After the suite admin has completed the tasks described previously, the tenant admin needs to perform the following tasks.

Assign the required role to the Service Management integration user

Tip If there's already an OPB Agent installed for the tenant, skip this step.

  1. Log in to the agent interface as the tenant admin.
  2. Navigate to Administration > Master Data > People, and then locate the integration user. If you don't see the user, click the Sync button. 
  3. Assign the OPB Remote Agent role to this user.

Configure tenant settings

  1. In the agent interface, navigate to Administration > Configuration > Application Settings.
  2. Check that the Enable Operations Orchestration option is set to On. This option is set to On by default. 
  3. If Service Management and OO Containerized use different FQDNs, in the Authorized domains for navigation field, enter the FQDN of OO Containerized. Skip this step if OO Containerized uses the same FQDN as Service Management.

This tenant setting controls the availability of the following UI items (which are available only when the tenant setting is On): 

  • The following option under Administration: Orchestration Settings
  • The following menu item under RUN: Automation Operations
  • The following role permission under Administration > People > Roles: Permission to manage Operations Orchestration
  • The following endpoint type under Administration > Utilities > Integration > Endpoints > Add > Endpoint type: Operations Orchestration Containerized

Note that the tenant setting doesn't control the visibility of the following item on the Role form (which is always available):

  • The Orchestration Settings option in the Administration menu visibility section:

Import the OO CA certificate into the OPB agent

  1. Log in to OO Containerized as the tenant admin. The login URL is in the following format: https://[host]:[port]/oo/?tenantId=xxxxxxxxxx. For example: https://myexamplehost:9443/oo/?tenantId=822946929.
  2. Export the OO CA certificate from the browser to a file in Base-64 encoded X.509 (.CER) format (for example, oo.cer). 
  3. Import the OO CA certificate into the OPB agent:
    1. Change to the following directory:  
      cd <OPB agent installation path>\product\util\3rd-party\jre\bin
    2. Copy the oo.cer file to this folder.
    3. Run the following command: 
      keytool -importcert -keystore ..\lib\security\cacerts -alias "ooserver" -file oo.cer

      When prompted, enter the keystore password (default: changeit).
      When prompted, type y to add the certificate to the OPB agent's trusted keystore.

    4. Restart the OPB agent.

Create an endpoint credentials record

Create an endpoint credentials record with the integration user that you have created for OO Containerized.

Launch OPB's Endpoint Credential Manager, and click New to create an endpoint credentials record for OO:

  • Endpoint type: Operations Orchestration Domain
  • User name and Password: enter the user name and password of the integration user that the suite admin has created for you.

Configure an OO endpoint

  1. From the main menu, select Administration > Utilities > Integration.
  2. Click the Endpoints tab, and then click Add and enter the endpoint details:
    • Endpoint type: select Operations Orchestration Containerized.
    • Endpoint name: enter a description. 
    • Running on agent: select the OPB agent that you added.
  3. Click Add.
  4. Configure the endpoint as given below.
    Field Description
    Endpoint name

    The name of the endpoint. This field is read-only.
    Credentials

    The list of credentials is populated automatically. Service Management queries the OPB agent for the list of credential records that were created in the Endpoint Credentials Manager.

    Select the credentials record of the OO integration user.

  5. Click Test connection to make sure that you can successfully connect to OO and then click Save.
  6. When the endpoint is configured, an automatic synchronization occurs, importing the Operations Orchestration content. If a change was made to the flow in Operations Orchestration after the endpoint was configured, you must perform the synchronization again manually by clicking Sync now.

Reuse existing OO endpoint

You can use an existing OO endpoint to create a new OO endpoint and maintain all your previously existing configurations, like workflow mapping and offering, in your new endpoint. 

Use the following steps to create a new OO endpoint from an existing endpoint configuration:

  1. Note the details of the existing endpoint. Example Endpoint1, take Name=Name1, EndPointId=EndPointId1.
  2. Create a new endpoint, Endpoint2, and assign it to same OPB Agent as the existing endpoint. Example for the new endpoint: Name=Name2, EndPointId=EndPointId2.

    : Don't run any sync task on Endpoint2.

  3. Backup Endpoint1 date in database xservices_rms with the following commands. 
    update maas_admin."OpbEndPointJSON_<TenantID>" set body=JSONB_SET(body, '{EndPointId}', '"EndPointId1_backup"') where body->>'EndPointId'='EndPointId1';
update maas_admin."OpbEndPointJSON_<TenantID>" set body=JSONB_SET(body, '{Name}', '"Name1_backup"') where body->>'Name'='Name1';
  4. Update Endpoint2 information with Endpoint1 for both Name and EndPointId. 
    update maas_admin."OpbEndPointJSON_<TenantID>" set body=JSONB_SET(body, '{Name}', '"Name1"') where body->>'Name'='Name2'; 
update maas_admin."OpbEndPointJSON_<TenantID>" set body=JSONB_SET(body, '{EndPointId}', '"EndPointId1"') where body->>'EndPointId'='EndPointId2';
  5. Check your workflow and offerings to verify if the mapping exists. You can verify by navigating to Studio > Process and Rules > Rules, then expand the After change tab. Alternatively, you can also go to Offerings > Service Offerings > Task Plan to confirm the new mappings exist.
  6. Go to Endpoint and trigger sync task with the new endpoint. 
  7. Confirm the workflow and offering mapping data are accurate.
  8. Run workflow and other tests to confirm the procedure was successful.

Verify the integration setup

  1. Log in to OO Containerized as the tenant admin: https://<host>:<port>/oo/?tenantId=<tenant_ID>.
  2. Create an OO flow, if you don't have an existing one. For details, see the OO documentation. 
  3. Run the OO flow from Service Management. For details, see Run OO flows from Service Management. 

Next, you can:

  • Assign OO roles and permissions to users
  • Configure orchestration settings
